articles.headline: Eli Broad, Who Helped Reshape Los Angeles, Dies at 87
articles.snippet: The businessman, who made a fortune in home-building and insurance, spent lavishly to try to make the city a cultural capital.
articles.abstract: The businessman, who made a fortune in home-building and insurance, spent lavishly to try to make the city a cultural capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eli Broad, a businessman and philanthropist whose vast fortune, extensive art collection and zeal for civic improvement helped reshape the cultural landscape of Los Angeles, died on Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 87.

articles.headline: Arnold Schwarzenegger Is No Longer the Governor of California. Right?
articles.snippet: Amid a pandemic and a recall, Mr. Schwarzenegger has been in demand at his Los Angeles mansion, embracing his unlikely role as California’s “elderly statesman.”
articles.abstract: Amid a pandemic and a recall, Mr. Schwarzenegger has been in demand at his Los Angeles mansion, embracing his unlikely role as California’s “elderly statesman.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Arnold Schwarzenegger settled into a big leather rocker recliner on the back patio of his mansion. His tiny rescue dog, Cherry, scampered at his feet, wearing a butterfly bow.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Seeks to Empower Poll Watchers, Raising Intimidation Worries
articles.snippet: Republicans in several states are pushing bills to give poll watchers more autonomy. Alarmed election officials and voting rights activists say it’s a new attempt to target voters of color.
articles.abstract: Republicans in several states are pushing bills to give poll watchers more autonomy. Alarmed election officials and voting rights activists say it’s a new attempt to target voters of color.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The red dot of a laser pointer circled downtown Houston on a map during a virtual training of poll watchers by the Harris County Republican Party. It highlighted densely populated, largely Black, Latino and Asian neighborhoods.

articles.headline: India’s Covid-19 Crisis Shakes Modi’s Image of Strength
articles.snippet: Overconfidence and missteps contributed to the country’s devastating second wave, his critics say, tarnishing the prime minister’s aura of political invulnerability.
articles.abstract: Overconfidence and missteps contributed to the country’s devastating second wave, his critics say, tarnishing the prime minister’s aura of political invulnerability.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — His Covid-19 task force didn’t meet for months. His health minister assured the public in March that India had reached the pandemic’s “endgame.” A few weeks before that, Prime Minister Narendra Modi boasted to global leaders that his nation had triumphed over the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Hari Kumar, Karan Deep Singh and Sameer Yasir

articles.headline: Biden’s Expansive Infrastructure Plan Hits Close to Home for McConnell
articles.snippet: President Biden’s infrastructure plan could fund a long-overdue revamp of the Brent Spence Bridge between Ohio and Kentucky. But the Senate Republican leader opposes it.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s infrastructure plan could fund a long-overdue revamp of the Brent Spence Bridge between Ohio and Kentucky. But the Senate Republican leader opposes it.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Early one November morning last year, a tractor-trailer hauling potassium hydroxide crashed into another truck that had jackknifed on the Brent Spence Bridge, igniting an enormous fire over the Ohio River that shut down the antiquated span connecting Cincinnati and northern Kentucky for six weeks.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Apple and Epic Head to Court Over Their Slices of the App Pie
articles.snippet: Apple and Epic Games, maker of the wildly popular game Fortnite, square off on Monday in a trial that could decide how much control Apple can exert over the app economy.
articles.abstract: Apple and Epic Games, maker of the wildly popular game Fortnite, square off on Monday in a trial that could decide how much control Apple can exert over the app economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: One Friday last August, Tim Sweeney, a billionaire game developer, sent an email to a contact at Microsoft: “You’ll enjoy the upcoming fireworks show.”
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Biden’s Proposals Aim to Give Sturdier Support to the Middle Class
articles.snippet: His message is that the private sector alone cannot provide security and comfort to the vast majority of Americans.
articles.abstract: His message is that the private sector alone cannot provide security and comfort to the vast majority of Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most striking difference between the middle class of 50 years ago and the middle class today is a loss of confidence — the confidence that you were doing better than your parents and that your children would do better than you.

articles.headline: ‘We’re Suffering’: How Remote Work Is Killing Manhattan’s Storefronts
articles.snippet: Landlords cut small retailers a break on rent during the pandemic, but stores are still struggling because too few office workers and tourists have returned.
articles.abstract: Landlords cut small retailers a break on rent during the pandemic, but stores are still struggling because too few office workers and tourists have returned.
articles.lead_paragraph: A big shift toward working from home is endangering hundreds of locally owned Manhattan storefronts that have been hanging on, waiting for life to return to the desolate streets of Midtown and the Financial District.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Matthew Haag

articles.headline: In South Texas, Hispanic Republicans Try to Cement the Party’s Gains
articles.snippet: Conservative Hispanic leaders, especially women, are ascendant in the Rio Grande Valley, where Republicans are trying to forge lasting bonds with voters who swung sharply to the right in 2020.
articles.abstract: Conservative Hispanic leaders, especially women, are ascendant in the Rio Grande Valley, where Republicans are trying to forge lasting bonds with voters who swung sharply to the right in 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Texas — The front door of the Hidalgo County Republican Party’s office is covered with photographs of high-profile politicians in the party: Gov. Greg Abbott, Senator John Cornyn and former President Donald J. Trump. Nearly all of them are white men.

articles.headline: How the A.T.F., Key to Biden’s Gun Plan, Became an N.R.A. ‘Whipping Boy’
articles.snippet: The federal agency tasked with enforcing gun laws has been hamstrung for years by the firearms lobby. Now, the president’s plan to rein in gun violence hinges on the A.T.F.’s success.
articles.abstract: The federal agency tasked with enforcing gun laws has been hamstrung for years by the firearms lobby. Now, the president’s plan to rein in gun violence hinges on the A.T.F.’s success.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARTINSBURG, W.Va. — If there was one moment that summed up the current state of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, it was when the floor at the agency’s gun-tracing center caved in a couple of years ago under the weight of paper.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Danny Hakim and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Verizon Near Deal to Sell Yahoo and AOL
articles.snippet: In making the deal with the private equity firm Apollo, Verizon is acknowledging that it couldn’t compete with Google and Facebook for digital ads. Instead, it will concentrate on building a 5G network.
articles.abstract: In making the deal with the private equity firm Apollo, Verizon is acknowledging that it couldn’t compete with Google and Facebook for digital ads. Instead, it will concentrate on building a 5G network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Verizon once saw media as the future, the linchpin of a strategy to give customers something they couldn’t get elsewhere at a time when all mobile offerings were essentially the same. It has a different vision for the future now.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: As Body Cameras Become Commonplace, a Debate Over When to Release the Footage
articles.snippet: The question of timing has become an unsettled new frontier of policymaking as the use of police body cameras is more the rule rather than the exception.
articles.abstract: The question of timing has become an unsettled new frontier of policymaking as the use of police body cameras is more the rule rather than the exception.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELIZABETH CITY, N.C. — Ma’Khia Bryant had been dead only a few hours when the authorities in Columbus, Ohio, released body camera footage from the police officer who had shot and killed her.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio

articles.headline: Help, We Can’t Stop Writing About Andrew Yang
articles.snippet: The outsider brings provocative ideas and good vibes. But can an “empty vessel” really make it through New York’s shark-infested media waters?
articles.abstract: The outsider brings provocative ideas and good vibes. But can an “empty vessel” really make it through New York’s shark-infested media waters?
articles.lead_paragraph: In January of last year, as the Iowa caucuses neared and before I’d heard of Covid-19, I asked Andrew Yang if running for mayor of New York wouldn’t make more sense than his improbable presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Why Biden’s Plan to Raise Taxes for Rich Investors Isn’t Hurting Stocks
articles.snippet: Investors care more about economic data and corporate profits than an increase in the capital gains tax. It has usually been this way.
articles.abstract: Investors care more about economic data and corporate profits than an increase in the capital gains tax. It has usually been this way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors have largely shrugged off President Biden’s proposal to raise taxes on investment income for wealthy Americans, as the stock market hovers near record highs after news of a strong economic rebound and blockbuster earnings reports from technology giants such as Apple and Amazon.

articles.headline: Wanted in France: Thousands of Workers as Hotels and Restaurants Reopen
articles.snippet: As the world’s most visited country prepares for a long-awaited economic reopening, hospitality businesses warn they are facing a labor shortfall.
articles.abstract: As the world’s most visited country prepares for a long-awaited economic reopening, hospitality businesses warn they are facing a labor shortfall.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For six months, Christophe Thiriet has been waiting for France’s grinding national lockdowns to be lifted so he can reopen his company’s restaurants and hotels in a picturesque corner of eastern France and recall the 150 employees who were furloughed months ago.

articles.headline: Widespread Commodity Shortages Raise Inflation Fears
articles.snippet: For products as diverse as lumber and microchips, price increases are filtering through the economy.
articles.abstract: For products as diverse as lumber and microchips, price increases are filtering through the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a normal year, Ron Whalen, vice president of Roger B. Kennedy Construction, receives one or two “Dear Valued Customer” letters from suppliers notifying him of price increases for certain materials. This year, a stack of 30 such warnings sits on his desk in Orlando, Fla., alerting him that things as diverse as lumber, drywall, aluminum and steel are going to cost 10 to 20 percent more.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Swiss Billionaire Quietly Becomes Influential Force Among Democrats
articles.snippet: Hansjörg Wyss, who recently dropped his bid to buy Tribune Publishing, has been a leading source of difficult-to-trace money to groups associated with Democrats.
articles.abstract: Hansjörg Wyss, who recently dropped his bid to buy Tribune Publishing, has been a leading source of difficult-to-trace money to groups associated with Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is not as well known as wealthy liberal patrons like George Soros or Tom Steyer. His political activism is channeled through a daisy chain of opaque organizations that mask the ultimate recipients of his money. But the Swiss billionaire Hansjörg Wyss has quietly become one of the most important donors to left-leaning advocacy groups and an increasingly influential force among Democrats.

articles.headline: Los Angeles Times Hires Its Next Top Editor: Kevin Merida, of ESPN
articles.snippet: One of the biggest newspaper jobs goes to a groundbreaking journalist who spent two decades at The Washington Post.
articles.abstract: One of the biggest newspaper jobs goes to a groundbreaking journalist who spent two decades at The Washington Post.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a six-month search, The Los Angeles Times announced on Monday that it had selected a seasoned journalist to take the publication deeper into its digital future and strengthen its news coverage: Kevin Merida, who spent more than two decades at The Washington Post before becoming an editor and senior vice president at ESPN.
